<u>Introductory <\u>
At the present day it is almost universally 
supposed that the corpus callosum of the human 
brain is a commissure  between corresponding 
convolutions of the two cerebral hemispheres.
Thus Meynert (Stricker’s Histology. Syd. Soc.) one of 
the greatest living authorities on the subject of the 
anatomico-physiological connections of the brain clearly 
<s>takes <\s> holds by this opinion. <s>He h Frons <\s> In the mic=
roscopic examination of the brains of small animals 
possessing a corpus callosum he believes that he 
has seen fibres running directly across from the 
one side to the other, and he concludes that <s>therefore <\s>
<s>they have <\s> the same arrangement prevails in Man.
[This view is reiterated by Huguenin (Allgemeine 
Pathologie der Krankheiten des Nervensystems 1. Theil 
S. 101) who regards it as constituted of intercon-
volutional fibres from corresponding parts of each 
hemisphere throughout the whole extent of the
